column4: why would you want / & /home on the same drive?  just put /home on a different partition,
there could be quite a few reasons for choosing to do that - for one, it is easier to image a single partition rather than two
does sudo work tho? or does it fail?
sudo works, it's just annoying and i never got that in the past.
/etc/hosts must have an entry for your HOSTNAME for sudo to be able to to resolve your hostname's IP address
what does this return?  grep $HOSTNAME /etc/hosts
i went into the /etc/hosts and added line 127.0.1.1 UP2 and now it works.
so your problem's resolved now?
cedega might be able to do it - though it costs...
i hear that cedega can't do it either.
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?p=5444476
setting up name resolution in samba.  http://oreilly.com/catalog/samba/chapter/book/ch07_03.html
confused :|
going to bed night
it's not a service, so you don't have to start it, just use it as and when needed
you might need to use sudo there
sorry, i misread
is /home/louie/Network a mount-point?
yes
what kind of a volume are you trying to mount there?  i mean, filesystem
i am trying to unmount it so i can delete it:  i followed a bad tutorial online
sudo umount /home/louie/Network
says device is busy?
do you have any files open on the volume? is your current directory /home/louie/Network ?
no not that i know of?
try this.  lsof | grep -i "/home/louie/Network"
bash       4452      louie  cwd       DIR       0,23      4096          1 /home/louie/Network
heh,  cd && sudo umount /home/louie/Network
cd  on it's own takes you to your $HOME directory
do you happen to have another terminal open?
no, there is another directory mounted:  i think it is inside of ~/Network
you'll need to umount that first then
hmm,  paste the output of the mount command to the pastebin.
http://paste.ubuntu.com/37923/
no, paste the output of  mount  not umount
just mount on its own
bahh.   which pastebinit || sudo aptitude install pastebinit;  pastebinit < <(mount)
that command will return a URL ..
http://pastebin.com/f10b7a846
does this still return anything?  lsof | grep -i "/home/louie/Network"
yes
bash       4452      louie  cwd       DIR       0,23      4096          1 /home/louie/Network
hmm. you still have a terminal/shell open that is accessing this directory ..
opening system-manager to investigate
you could just kill that pid.  kill 4452
it turns back nothing!!! whoot, fusesmb was still running in the background
i killed fusesmb and it unmounted. cool
that's a bit unsafe .. you should run an fsck on the device now to make sure
just run sudo fsck now?
how should i fsck it?
how should i fsck it?
it was a bit unclear from your mount output which network volume was mounted there - basically you want to fsck the device that housed the shared directory
so the device that housed ~/Network?
no, the device that housed the shared directory that was mounted on ~/Network ..
this might be on a remote machine
that was my computer's home directory...
i'm confused .. you mounted a local share on a local directory?
ok, then you fsck the device that houses the home directory
that might require you to step down into single user mode and unmount the device first
yes
chkdsk in windows safe mode
he cannot access windows
well, only the windows tools can reliably restore the volume .. so you might want to investigate more on this in ##windows
and how is he trying to mount this device now?
usser:    sudo ntfs-3g /dev/sdc1 /mount/Window_Corrupt -o force
he's got the command all wrong
when he plugged in that command it went through successfully
so where can his drive now?
use mount to find out
just type in mount?
yes
usser:  it worked thank you
pm-suspend  # but it isn't the command used when suspending
when i put that in, it ways that it must be run as root, but i don't have to press the button on gnome-panel as root?
like i said, it isn't the command used in suspending
that one works, so do you know what the command is actually?
the gnome-power-manager (or equivalent) and acpi handle it using system calls, etc - no commands really used in the process
what?  can you tell me what/where i can look to see what command occurs when i press that button
what's unclear about my language? i said no commands are used
how can no commands be used?!  Last time it was gnome-pwr-cmd, but that is no longer available?
maybe you need to define 'commands'. do you mean shell commands or API calls?
lol.  what  i want to do is link a key combination to a command, or api call, so my computer suspends.
see http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=813387&page=2
as the forums says; the shortcut isn't working...
but this guy claims it does - http://ubuntuforums.org/showpost.php?p=8309702&postcount=16
right yah lowre down.  how does the gui suspend w/o a command/sudo pw?
he uses the DBUS command line interface to send DBUS messages to the power manager - not really a command per se and it doesn't require root/sudo privileges
is there a way to bind my command to that?
yea, the code is for a shell script, copy it into a text file, save it, make it executable and then call it passing the appropriate argument/parameter i.e. 'suspend' or 'hibernate'
haha. ohk :)
YES! thanks!
i am also having issues with notifications in empathy?
where are custom keybindings saved?  i am still getting an error that gnome-pwr-cmd cannot be found :(
